clauses.question: 1. What process should the Government use to set a new emissions reduction target in legislation?
clauses.answer: The Government sets a 2050 target in legislation now
clauses.notes:
Enshrining a target in legislation ensures we all have something to aim for and can begin innovation, system change and adaption.
 The alternative of waiting for some later target is that we all vacillate until something is firmed up, or political change waters down our

 targets.

clauses.question: 2. If the Government sets a 2050 target now, which is the best target for New Zealand?
clauses.answer: Net Zero Long-Lived Gases and Stabilised Short-Lived Gases - Long-lived gases to net zero by 2050 while also stabilising short-lived gases
clauses.notes:
Clearly there are differences in the way short and long lived gases are generated and behave. By splitting them it means certain

 sectors like agriculture have an incentive to innovate to counteract the short lived gases like methane, but, are not penalised in the
 longer term.

clauses.question: 3. How should New Zealand meet its targets?
clauses.answer: Domestic emissions reductions (including from new forest planting) and using some emissions reductions from overseas (international carbon units) that have strong environmental safeguards
clauses.notes:
I believe there will need to be a mix at the end of the day, and not constraining ourselves to domestic only reduction allows some

 flexibility and innovation to be part of that reduction. This won't absolve our need to move strongly and quickly domestically,
 particularly as the price of units is likely to grow

clauses.question: 4. Should the Zero Carbon Bill allow the 2050 target to be revised if circumstances change?
5. The Government proposes that three emissions budgets of five years each (i.e. covering the next 15 years) be in place at any given time. Do you agree with this proposal?
clauses.notes: Yes, this will help keep us all on target and avoid procrastination as businesses

clauses.question: 6. Should the Government be able to alter the last emissions budget (i.e. furthest into the future)?
clauses.answer: Yes - the third emissions budget should be able to be changed but only when the subsequent budget is set

clauses.question: 7. Should the Government have the ability to review and adjust the second emissions budget within a specific range under exceptional circumstances? See p36 Our Climate Your Say
8. Do you agree with the considerations we propose that the Government and the Climate Change Commission take into account when advising on and setting budgets? See p44 Our Climate Your Say
clauses.notes: Yes, this seems to be an appropriate mix of advice and monitoring

clauses.question: 9. Should the Zero Carbon Bill require Governments to set out plans within a certain timeframe to achieve the emissions budgets?
clauses.notes: Yes, strongly agree, without targets we won't progress strongly and consistently enough.

clauses.question: 10. What are the most important issues for the Government to consider in setting plans to meet budgets? For example, who do we need to work with, what else needs to be considered?
clauses.notes:
Wide consultation will be required, particularly to set plans allowing for innovations that have or are occurring and also to allow for
previously unforeseen or market reactions and consequences, that mean our targets and now too high or too low.

clauses.question: 11. The Government has proposed that the Climate Change Commission advises on and monitors New Zealand's progress towards its goals. Do you agree with these functions? See p42 Our Climate Your Say
12. What role do you think the Climate Change Commission should have in relation to the New Zealand Emissions Trading Scheme (NZ ETS)?
clauses.answer: Advising the Government on policy settings in the NZ ETS

clauses.question: 13. The Government has proposed that Climate Change Commissioners need to have a range of essential and desirable expertise. Do you agree with the proposed expertise? See p45 Our Climate Your Say
clauses.notes:
Yes, I agree that they have sector group expertise rather than be stakeholder representatives. Stakeholder voices are important, but
can be catered for in consultative groups that the Commissioners interact with on a periodic basis. This avoids 'captured interest' by
any particular sector.

clauses.question: 14. Do you think the Zero Carbon Bill should cover adapting to climate change?
clauses.notes: Yes, in the sense that adaptation will be a key part of meeting reduction targets and will greatly help alignment across all agencies

clauses.question: 15. The Government has proposed a number of new functions to help us adapt to climate change. Do you agree with the proposed functions? See p47 Our Climate Your Say
clauses.notes: Yes, agree with all of those

clauses.question: 16. Should we explore setting up a targeted adaptation reporting power that could see some organisations share information on their exposure to climate change risks?
clauses.notes: Yes, this will help transparency and our understanding of the risks and opportunities
